answer_html: It follows now, since \(f(x_1) = y\) and \(x_1 \in C \cap D\) that \(y \in f(C \cap D)\) as claimed.
answer_latex:
It follows now, since $f(x_1) = y$ and
$x_1 \in C \cap D$ that $y \in f(C \cap D)$ as claimed.
hints_html: Remember that to show that two sets X and Y are equal, you must show that X \(\subseteq\) Y and that Y \(\subseteq\) X.
hints_latex:
Remember that to show that two sets \emph{X} and \emph{Y} are equal, you
must show that \emph{X} $\subseteq$ \emph{Y} and that \emph{Y} $\subseteq$ \emph{X}.
hints_raw: Remember that to show that two sets ''X'' and ''Y'' are equal, you must show that ''X'' &sube; ''Y'' and that ''Y'' &sube; ''X''.
sols_html:
We want to show that

\[\begin{aligned} f(C \cap D) \subseteq f(C) \cap f(D)\end{aligned}\]

and that

\[\begin{aligned} f(C) \cap f(D) \subseteq f(C \cap D)\end{aligned}\]

Let us start with the first.

Suppose that \(y \in f(C \cap D)\); that is, there is some \(x \in C \cap D\) such that \(f(x) = y\). Since \(x \in C\) and \(x \in D\), it follows that \(y \in f(C)\) and that \(y \in f(D)\), i.e. that \(y \in f(C) \cap f(D)\) as desired.

Note: This proof in no way uses injectivity; this is a general statement about all functions.

Now we prove the second statement. Suppose that \(y \in f(C) \cap f(D)\). That is, \(y \in f(C)\) and \(y \in f(D)\). Equivalently, there is some \(x_1 \in C\) such that \(f(x_1) = y\), and some \(x_2 \in D\) such that \(f(x_2) = y\). We claim that \(x_1 = x_2\), and hence \(x_1 = x_2 \in C \cap D\). But this follows immediately from the injectivity of \(f\). It follows now, since \(f(x_1) = y\) and \(x_1 \in C \cap D\) that \(y \in f(C \cap D)\) as claimed.

f(C) \cap f(D) \subseteq f(C \cap D)
\end{align*} Let us start with the first.

Suppose that $y \in f(C \cap D)$; that is, there is some
$x \in C \cap D$ such that $f(x) = y$. Since $x \in C$ and $x \in D$, it
follows that $y \in f(C)$ and that $y \in f(D)$, i.e. that
$y \in f(C) \cap f(D)$ as desired.

\emph{Note: This proof in no way uses injectivity; this is a general
statement about all functions}.

Now we prove the second statement. Suppose that $y \in f(C) \cap f(D)$.
That is, $y \in f(C)$ and $y \in f(D)$. Equivalently, there is some
$x_1 \in C$ such that $f(x_1) = y$, and some $x_2 \in D$ such that
$f(x_2) = y$. We claim that $x_1 = x_2$, and hence
$x_1 = x_2 \in C \cap D$. But this follows immediately from the
injectivity of $f$. It follows now, since $f(x_1) = y$ and
$x_1 \in C \cap D$ that $y \in f(C \cap D)$ as claimed.
sols_raw:
We want to show that
:<math>
f(C \cap D) \subseteq f(C) \cap f(D)
</math>
and that
:<math>
f(C) \cap f(D) \subseteq f(C \cap D)
</math>
Let us start with the first.

Suppose that <math>y \in f(C \cap D)</math>; that is, there is some <math>x \in C \cap D</math> such that <math>f(x) = y</math>. Since <math>x \in C</math> and <math>x \in D</math>, it follows that <math>y \in f(C)</math> and that <math>y \in f(D)</math>, i.e. that <math>y \in f(C) \cap f(D)</math> as desired.

''Note: This proof in no way uses injectivity; this is a general statement about all functions''.

Now we prove the second statement. Suppose that <math>y \in f(C) \cap f(D)</math>. That is, <math>y \in f(C)</math> and <math>y \in f(D)</math>. Equivalently, there is some <math>x_1 \in C</math> such that <math>f(x_1) = y</math>, and some <math>x_2 \in D</math> such that <math>f(x_2) = y</math>. We claim that <math>x_1 = x_2</math>, and hence <math>x_1 = x_2 \in C \cap D</math>. But this follows immediately from the injectivity of <math>f</math>. It follows now, since <math>f(x_1) = y</math> and <math>x_1 \in C \cap D</math> that <math>y \in f(C \cap D)</math> as claimed.
statement_html:
Let \(f\): A \(\rightarrow\) B be a function. If C \(\subseteq\) A, define

\[\begin{aligned} f(C) = \{f(x) \mid x \in C\}\end{aligned}\]

Prove that if \(f\) is injective, then

\[\begin{aligned} f(C \cap D) = f(C) \cap f(D) \quad\text{for all sets } C, D \subseteq A\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Let &fnof;: ''A'' &rarr; ''B'' be a function. If ''C'' &sube; ''A'', define

:<math>
f(C) = \{f(x) \mid x \in C\}
</math>

Prove that if &fnof; is injective, then
:<math>
f(C \cap D) = f(C) \cap f(D) \quad\text{for all sets } C, D \subseteq A
</math>
